more than 35 years after it was released
I don't think there's any movie that
captures the chaos and intensity of
democratic politics quite as well as
Michael Ritchie's the candidate from
1972 it stars Robert Redford as an
idealistic young lawyer running for a US
Senate seat from California McKay the
character of Bill McKay is loosely based
on California Governor Jerry Brown and
the movie is full of some details that
mark it as a product of the early 1970s
but what's remarkable about the
candidate is how much it seems to
predict about subsequent developments in
American political culture for one thing
it's a movie that reflects a nascent
obsession with the ins and outs of the
political process part of this is the
character of Marvin Lucas the political
consultant who in a way predicts the
emergence of the political consultant as
media celebrity you look at him and you
see the prototype of George
Stephanopoulos James Carville Karl Rove
and if you look at Bill McKay you can
seem to be looking at a lot of real-life
candidates senator and then Vice
President Dan Quayle was said to have
modeled his career on Robert Redford's
bill McKay you can also catch a
premonition of Gary Hart of Bill Clinton
and maybe have a certain other young
idealistic lawyer think of it the
biggest the richest the most powerful
country cannot keep its full job force
working the candidates a lot of fun
smart maybe a little bit cynical I say
to you can't any longer
oh no can any longer play off black
against old
young against poor this country cannot
house its houseless feed its foodless it
gives you a wonderfully immediate
feeling of the rhythms of a modern
campaign the television commercials the
missteps the gaffes the debates the
late-night consultations all of the pomp
and circumstance and chaos and energy
that make democracy such a kick but at
the end when all of that's over and the
votes have been counted we're still all
left asking a very basic very serious
question what do we do now
